people_also_viewed.summary:
Prakhar Sinha
        
              
          A few short days ago, I wrapped up my research position at UC Davis Health with Professor Farzad Fereidouni. My role at the lab entailed a specialization in machine learning and computer vision and I'm excited to share what I was able to accomplish with everyone. 

I worked on two projects during my time at the lab. The first one was something I called "Kernel Generation for Image Similarity" (https://lnkd.in/ghsY73ts). It was to process an image such that it would look like it was H&E stained. I learned a lot about the basics of histology and digital histology through this process. The most novel part of this approach was using Wiener deconvolution to generate a kernel that would be used to enhance image similarity (typically using SSIM, MSE or a combination of both). 

A big part of this process was optimization. I learned how to use Python libraries such as Cupy and other tools to GPU accelerate a lot of these image-processing optimization problems.

My second project and my most meaningful contribution was called "FastSAM-needle-biopsy" (https://lnkd.in/gXXydq-X). The objective of this project was to use the FastSAM image segmentation network to accurately generate image segmentation masks of live tissue such that a microscope would only scan the relevant parts of an image. Here is step by step walkthrough of the image processing pipeline:

1) VB.NET (Darius) application calls a DLL (compiled from csharp.NET)
2) DLL calls FastSAM image segmentation code using Python.NET
3) FastSAM segments image and returns image segmentation bitmask and as well as the fastest path to visit every bit (Traveling Salesman Problem)
4) Python returns values are returned to DLL using JSON as a reliable data transfer solution 
5) DLL returns an object that can be parsed by VB.NET

FastSAM is a faster version of Meta Research's Segment Anything Model and I used it to greatly speed up development time on this project. It was a big challenge to integrate such cutting-edge, machine-learning driven, image processing pipelines into a legacy codebase that was written in Visual Basic .NET but thanks to tools such as DLLs, JSON, and C#, I was able to figure it out!

I am very grateful for the time I spent in the lab. I feel like I developed some great programming skills, especially in computer vision, that will prove useful for the rest of my career. I'd like to give special thanks to Professor Fereidouni, Ruby Mascareno, Willy Ju, Dena Sayrafi, Ruben Gnanaruban, Inyola, Antara Mallick, and Jayla. 

The link is here if you'd like to see my lab report going over everything I did in more technical detail and with a few pictures!

https://lnkd.in/gRpZVmjG

#computervision #machinelearning #AI #histology

          🎉 Excited to share my latest project: an AI-powered Anime Recommendation Agent! 🎉

I’ve been working on building an anime recommendation system that not only suggests anime based on your favorite genres or anime titles but also provides detailed information about each show—including descriptions and genres—right from the terminal! 🚀

Using the AniList API, I developed a system that makes anime discovery super easy and fun. Whether you’re a fan of action-packed shonen, heartwarming slice-of-life, or mind-bending psychological thrillers, this AI agent has got you covered! 💡

🎬 I’m thrilled to share a demo video of the project, showcasing how the AI agent works in real-time, helping you find your next binge-worthy series with ease.
Stay tuned and check out the video! 👇

#AnimeAI #RecommendationSystem #AniListAPI #AIProjects #MachineLearning #AnimeLover #DataScience #TechInnovation #AIDevelopment #TerminalAgent #AnimeTech

Md. Faiyaz Abdullah Sayeedi
        
              
          NVIDIA claims - AI ‘healthcare revolution’ already under way

Healthcare is probably the most impactful utility of generative AI that there will be. With generative AI, we’re going to be able to not only generate more ideas and predict with better accuracy, but we’re also going to be able to model biology in new and exciting ways so that when we put a new chemical entity into the clinic, we have a higher success rate. If you think about an ultrasound, or even robotic surgery and self-driving cars, they’re not that different. There’s lots of sensor data coming in, so there are real-time decisions being made. 

Generative AI will also be crucial in postoperative and follow-up medical treatment stages, such as when compiling a post-treatment report with patient data or reviewing a past surgery to assess its success.

Source: https://lnkd.in/g5vBu6a8

#AI #Healthcare #GenAI #Revolution

Tinevimbo Musingadi
        
              
          AI, Agents, and Devin😨… Worried about your job? Don’t be! 😱

Using Cursor to build Vector Notebook

I'm thrilled to be building Vector Notebook with Cursor as my go-to code editor. What's Cursor? 🤔 It’s the best AI-powered code editor developed by Anysphere. Don't worry, Cursor won’t take your job, but it will make programming a lot less stressful. 😌

What makes Cursor special?
Fully autonomous agents are impressive, but there's something even more powerful: the collaboration between humans and AI. As technology evolves (especially reasoning models), human + AI collaboration becomes even more effective. Personally, Cursor has boosted my productivity by 100x, and it’s now my favorite code editor. 💻🚀

The Cursor team Michael T.  Sualeh A.  Arvid Lunnemark and Aman Sanger  phenomenal. I’ve learned a lot from their insightful blog posts and interviews, which have greatly influenced my work. One feature I find particularly fascinating is their variant of speculative decoding called speculative edits, which is super useful when developing agentic systems that write and execute code. 🔥 This week, I’ve been diving into a small research project to develop speculative algorithms using Bayesian optimization. If the experiment works out 😭, expect a paper soon!

If you're interested in enhancing your workflow, I highly recommend downloading Cursor. While you do, check out this podcast 🎧 by Lex Fridman, where he featured the founding team: https://lnkd.in/dtewW8Na.

Tools like Cursor show that human + AI collaboration is incredibly effective 😅. This is the direction Vector Notebook will be taking—not as a tool to replace data and computational scientists, but as a tool to boost their productivity. Just like how Cursor has made developing Vector Notebook a less stressful and fun! 💪🔥

Danaa Younus
        
              
          🚀 Unveiling Our Flask Application for Heart Disease Prediction! 🫀✨



Last Semester, my friends Samreen Riaz, Afroze Najam and I made a Flask based application as our semester project for our AI course. 



The solution combines data analysis, visualizations, and a user-friendly Flask web application for real-time predictions. Here's an overview of our journey:



The Data Journey:

📂 Dataset: Explored and preprocessed a rich dataset of medical parameters.

Checked for missing values, duplicates, and inconsistencies.

Encoded categorical variables and scaled features for optimal ML performance.

Visualized relationships using box plots, histograms, scatter plots, and bar charts.


Machine Learning Magic:

⚙️ Leveraged Logistic Regression with:

Train-Test Split: To ensure robust model evaluation.

Cross-Validation: For consistent performance assessment.

Metrics: AUC, confusion matrices, precision, recall, and F1 scores.

Key outcomes:

Accuracy: Achieved promising results on both train and test datasets.

Insights: Identified key feature correlations with heart disease.



What do you think about this project? Any feedback or suggestions are welcome! Let’s make a difference, one prediction at a time. 😊



#MachineLearning #Flask #DataScience #HeartDisease #WebDevelopment #HealthcareInnovation

Xiaomei Song
        
              
          I'm excited to share that this semester, I completed two AI agent projects and am continuing work on another AI agent project. Today I want to highlight one of them!
🚀 Project Overview This project focused on developing multimodal multiple AI agents and bots in an open-ended game environment, enabling reasoning, planning, and adaptability through specialized components:
🔹 Vision Agent: Provides spatial information, pathfinding, and temporal data for vision-informed planning and task proposals. It also incorporates Tree of Thought reasoning to enhance spatial analysis, improve task proposals, and dynamically update strategies based on observed patterns. 
🔹 Curriculum Agent: Dynamically generates tasks to maximize exploration and skill acquisition, adapting based on insights from the Vision Agent and environment context. It leverages Tree of Thought Planning to break down complex goals into hierarchical subtasks, explore multiple reasoning paths, and optimize task sequences through recursive evaluation.
 🔹 Action Agent: Executes complex behaviors through code generation, iterative refinement, and environment feedback, leveraging a shared skill library for long-horizon tasks. 
🔹 Critic Agent: Evaluates task outcomes using visual and contextual data, providing feedback to refine strategies and improve decision-making. It employs Tree of Thought Evaluation to assess intermediate steps, validate alternative reasoning paths, and refine outputs based on logical consistency. 🔹 Skill Manager: Stores and retrieves executable behaviors, enabling continuous learning and scalability for complex tasks.
🤖 Multi-Bot System I also developed a multi-bot system that extends the Voyager framework, enabling multiple bots to operate concurrently in the same Minecraft world. Managed through a Multi-Agent Manager, each bot runs independently, communicates via REST APIs, and shares environmental states. This setup supports collaboration, skill sharing, and scalable task management with robust error recovery.
🌟 Inspired by Voyager Building on the Voyager project, which uses large language models for exploration and skill acquisition, this work demonstrates the potential of AI-driven automation and adaptability.
🔗 Explore the Project Check it out on GitHub: https://lnkd.in/gHHvrBTs
Watch the demo video: https://lnkd.in/gdiNx44Y
🙌 Special thanks to Alberto and Francesco for their contributions along the way!

ThankGod Eboreime
        
              
          🚀 Excited to Share My Latest Project: An AI-Powered Pantry Tracker! 🚀

I’m thrilled to present my Week 2 submission for Headstarter: AI Pantry Tracker. 

This web app is designed to streamline pantry management using Google Gen AI by allowing users to classify pantry images and add, edit, and delete pantry items effortlessly. 🥫✨

Key features:
Add & Edit Items: Seamlessly add pantry items with details like name, quantity, expiry date, category, and image.
AI Image Classification: Leverage AI to classify your pantry items and suggest names and categories.
Categorization: Pantry items are organized into categories automatically when classified using AI.

Built with Next js, Langchain, Google Gen AI (model: gemini-1.5-flash), TypeScript, Material UI, and Firebase, this project aims to enhance pantry organization and efficiency using AI. 

Thanks to Headstarter for the opportunity to dive into this project! 🙌

🔗 Live Link: https://lnkd.in/dX4exnWY
      Github: https://lnkd.in/dEFgExj9

#HeadstarterAI #PantryTracker #WebDevelopment #ReactJS #TypeScript #Firebase #AI #TechInnovation #Frontend #Fullstack

Ajay Mallya
        
              
          I'm grateful to have had the opportunity to travel back to dear NYC for a couple of days and present about some fundamental theoretical components of the Aerospike vector database. Thank you Microsoft and PyData NYC for hosting and putting on this event, and thank you Arthur Anderson for your wonderful portion of the presentation! (Side remark: after the presentation, I was absolutely stoked when someone told me that I should be a professor after college 😄)

I'm taking advantage of this post to provide a few small updates: Going forward, I'll be working on more software engineering tasks with the Aerospike Graph team, and I'll simultaneously learn more about distributed systems, get deeper into algorithmic design & analysis, and spend more time with C++. I plan to post something more reflective about my gap semester experience and what I have learned , but here is a list of some other things that I have enjoyed recently outside of my internship:

- 📓 Reengaging with my Applied Mathematics courses in nontraditional ways. Without exams to study for, I've taken full advantage of this time to relearn a slew of topics from original principles, and this has been a tremendously fruitful and satisfying process. Additionally, considering the context in which mathematical concepts were discovered has boosted my appreciation for my interests. I highly recommend "The History of Mathematical Proof in Ancient Traditions" by Karine Chemla if the math-history intersection intrigues you. 

- 🥾 Getting outdoors more often. Whether it's walking my dog, running, or backpacking for a couple of days, I've been making a conscious effort to rejuvenate my mind and avoid any shred of mental stagnancy at all costs. Side note: I saw my first barn owl last night (indeed, I love birdwatching). 

- 📚 🇫🇷 Cultivating a couple of daily habits. I have made doing (duo-ing?) my Duolingo lessons a priority, and I now realize that my years of Latin are finally paying off with other European languages. I've also made daily reading a priority, and I have set a fairly modest goal of one book a month. I'm right on track so far!

I'm very proud of (1) my work and (2) my work-life balance thus far, and I'm absolutely looking forward to the upcoming academic year. There are various reflections that I've unearthed over the past 6 months or so, and I certainly plan to articulate them here towards the end of this summer!

Adel Fabián del Valle Pérez
        
              
          Hello LinkedIn! 

This semester I took the challenge of branching out to ECE. I ended up doing this research project, where I combined my passion for Design of Algorithms to achieve Computational Savings in Deep Neural Networks. 

I proposed to implement Hashing, in specific, Localitity Sensitive Hashing, but with a twist, to group weights by similarity, choose a weight representative by bucket, and prune the ones who were not the representative. 

This not only ended up with computational savings (same performance with 99% less FLOPs, and 99% less parameters), but also acted as a form of regularization for better generalization. 

🌟  Here is the GitHub repo: https://lnkd.in/gdsCHWGe 

There is still more to add to this research project, and I am looking forward to do it in the followig months.

Seungwoo Son
        
              
          🎉 Excited to share that two of my recent projects have been accepted to major AI conferences!

🙌 Huge thanks to my amazing collaborators ryu jegwang, Wonpyo Park, Woohyun Han, Kyuyeun Kim, Namhoon Lee, Jaeho Lee from #Google and #POSTECH!

1️⃣ MaskedKD has been accepted to #ECCV2024! This work introduces a method for reducing the supervision cost in distilling ViTs. By masking input tokens based on student attention scores, we can save up to 50% of teacher FLOPs while maintaining student accuracy.

[Preprint: https://lnkd.in/gUJn4D3a]

2️⃣ CushionCache, a project from my Google internship, has been accepted to #EMNLP2024 main track! We introduce a novel method to mitigate activation outliers in LLMs, significantly improving activation quantization and enhancing generation quality. Our approach discovers a prefix (the CushionCache) that regularizes activations and reduces quantization errors.

[Preprint: https://lnkd.in/gtArpEF2]

Abdulvahap Mutlu
        
              
          New Project!

I'm excited to share my latest project on EEG Eye State Classification! 🧠👁️

In this project, I utilized EEG signals to classify eye states (open or closed) using various machine learning models. The dataset, sourced from a continuous EEG measurement with the Emotiv EEG Neuroheadset, provided a fascinating challenge.

Project Highlights:

🔍 Dataset: EEG Eye State from UCI Machine Learning Repository 

🛠️ Technologies: Python, Pandas, Scikit-Learn, Matplotlib, Seaborn 

📈 Models Used:
Logistic Regression
Random Forest
Support Vector Machine (SVM)
Gradient Boosting

Key Results:
Logistic Regression: Accuracy - 61%
Random Forest: Accuracy - 93%
SVM: Accuracy - 87%
Gradient Boosting: Accuracy - 95%

I applied hyperparameter tuning to optimize each model, achieving the best performance with Gradient Boosting. 🎯

Check out the full project on GitHub for detailed code, visualizations, and results:
🔗 https://lnkd.in/drUkbKxF

I believe this project serves as a compelling demonstration of my proficiency in machine learning and my ability to apply these skills to EEG signal analysis. It exemplifies the integration of EEG signals with machine learning techniques, showcasing practical applications in this domain. Additionally, it was an enjoyable and intellectually stimulating endeavor.

Feel free to connect with me if you have any questions or insights to share!

#MachineLearning #DataScience #EEG #DeepLearning #Python #AI #ArtificialIntelligence #DataAnalysis #OpenSource

Ian S.
        
              
          Thrilled to share that my paper, "Engaging and Entertaining Adolescents in Health Education Using LLM-Generated Fantasy Narrative Games and Virtual Agents," will be presented at the ACM CHI conference in Honolulu, Hawaii!

💻🎮 Can video games make health education fun AND effective? We used large language models (LLM), specifically GPT-4, to create interactive interventions about the HPV vaccine. One was a traditional pedagogical agent, the other an immersive fantasy adventure.

✅ The results? Both formats improved knowledge and acceptance of the HPV vaccine, but the fantasy game was more engaging and entertaining. Importantly, we found that LLMs could help streamline game development, though human oversight is essential to ensure accuracy.

Key Takeaway: Narrative games using LLMs could be powerful tools to spark important health conversations within families, combating rising vaccine hesitancy.

Paper Link: https://lnkd.in/eD8baufM

#CHI2024 #AI  #education #HPV #generativeai #videogames #health
